title: 1.1: First Emission
summary: Create your first particle system with basic blocks
intro: In this lesson, you'll learn how to create a simple particle system using the Node Particle Editor. We'll start with the fundamental blocks: System, Update Position, and Create Particle.
steps: Create a <filter-value>System</filter-value> block - this is the root of your particle system
Add a <filter-value>Texture</filter-value> block to provide a texture for the particles and connect to System block
Load a <textures>flare.png</textures> by load button in the Texture block properties
Add a <filter-value>CreateParticle</filter-value> block to emit particles and connect to System block
Add a <filter-value>BoxShape</filter-value> block to emit particles from a box volume and connect between CreateParticle and System blocks
Add an <filter-value>UpdatePosition</filter-value> block to handle particle movement and connect between BoxShape and System blocks
Add a <filter-value>Position</filter-value> block to get the current position and connect to UpdatePosition block
Add a <filter-value>ScaledDirection</filter-value> block to get the scaled direction
Add a math <filter-value>Add</filter-value> block to combine position and direction and connect Position and ScaledDirection blocks to the left and right inputs respectively
Connect the result from the math block to UpdatePosition's position input

blocks.name: System Block
blocks.description: The root block of any particle system. It manages the overall system properties and connects to all particle-related blocks. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and configure its properties in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Name
properties.description: The display name of the particle system. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

blocks.name: Update Position Block
blocks.description: Updates the position of particles each frame. This block is essential for any particle movement. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and configure its properties in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Name
properties.description: The display name of the block. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

blocks.name: Create Particle Block
blocks.description: Creates new particles. This block is responsible for particle emission. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and configure its properties in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Name
properties.description: The display name of the block. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

blocks.name: Box Shape Block
blocks.description: Defines a box-shaped emitter. Particles will be created within this box volume. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and configure its properties in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Name
properties.description: The display name of the emitter. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

blocks.name: Input Block
blocks.description: Retrieves contextual particle data such as position, velocity, or age. In this lesson, we use it to get the current position and scaled direction. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and set its contextual value in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Contextual Value
properties.description: The type of contextual data to retrieve. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

blocks.name: Math Block
blocks.description: Performs mathematical operations on particle data. We use it to add position and direction vectors. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and set its operation in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Operation
properties.description: The mathematical operation to perform (Add, Subtract, Multiply, Divide, etc.). Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

blocks.name: Texture Source Block
blocks.description: Provides a texture for particles. This determines how particles look when rendered. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and load a texture using the load button in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Texture URL
properties.description: The URL of the texture image to use. Load this using the load button in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

codeCopy: The code creates a NodeParticleSystemSet and builds a graph of connected blocks. Each block has a specific function, and they're connected visually in the editor.
objectives: Understand the basic structure of a particle system
Learn how to connect blocks visually in the editor
Create particles using Create Particle and Box Shape blocks
Use Input blocks to retrieve contextual particle data like Position and Scaled Direction
Apply mathematical operations to combine position and direction using Math blocks
Understand the particle flow: Create Particle → Box Shape → Update Position → System

commonMistakes.mistake: Forgetting to connect blocks in the correct order
commonMistakes.explanation: Blocks must be connected in a logical flow. The Create Particle block must connect to a shape, then to update blocks, and finally to the System block.
commonMistakes.solution: Follow the chain: Create Particle → Box Shape → Update Position → System. Connect each block's output to the next block's input by dragging connections in the editor.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using wrong contextual value in Input block
commonMistakes.explanation: Input blocks can retrieve different types of data (Position, Direction, Age, etc.). Using the wrong type will give incorrect results.
commonMistakes.solution: Check the contextual value in the Input block's properties panel on the right. Make sure it matches what you need (Position, Scaled Direction, etc.).

commonMistakes.mistake: Not connecting the final result to System block
commonMistakes.explanation: The System block is the root of the particle system. If update blocks aren't connected to it, particles won't be updated.
commonMistakes.solution: Always connect the last update block (Update Position) to the System block. Drag the connection from Update Position's output to System block's particle input.

homework: Try changing the Box Shape block to a different shape (Cone, Sphere, etc.)
Experiment with different texture URLs in the Texture block
Modify the Math block operation to see how it affects particle movement
Add more particles by adjusting the Create Particle block settings in the properties panel
